name: Autonomous Things
description: Robots, drones, and autonomous vehicles would use AI to perform tasks previously done by humans, operating in both controlled and open environments.
accuracyNote: Predicted robots, drones, and autonomous vehicles operating in open environments. Warehouse robots made incremental progress; delivery drones remain niche; autonomous vehicles are still not mainstream in 2026. The timeline was far too aggressive and the physical autonomy vision largely didn't materialize.

name: Augmented Analytics
description: AI and ML would automate data preparation, insight generation, and sharing of insights, making analytics accessible to business users rather than just data scientists.
accuracyNote: The prediction described traditional ML automating ETL and insight discovery. What actually made analytics accessible was LLM-based natural language querying (Copilot-style analytics). The outcome matches but via different technology than described.

name: AI-Driven Development
description: AI would be integrated into development tools and processes, automating testing, code generation, and application design. Professional developers would use AI assistants.
accuracyNote: Predicted AI automating testing and design via traditional ML. What happened (Copilot, Cursor, Claude Code) is fundamentally different — LLM-powered code generation rather than ML-based SDLC automation. Right area, completely wrong mechanism.

name: Digital Twins
description: Digital twins would expand beyond IoT into modeling organizations, processes, and entire ecosystems, becoming key decision-support tools.
accuracyNote: Physical asset twins grew well. Organizational and process twins remain aspirational. The technology works but adoption is slower than predicted across most industries.

name: Empowered Edge
description: Edge computing would bring computation and data storage closer to the sources of data, enabling faster processing and reduced bandwidth requirements.
accuracyNote: Edge computing found niches (CDN workers, some IoT) but the prediction implied it would be much more transformative. Edge devices doing significant local computation remains limited. A useful niche, not the revolution described.

name: Immersive Experience
description: Conversational platforms, AR, and VR would change how users perceive and interact with the digital world, creating multimodal, multi-sensory experiences.
accuracyNote: The prediction emphasized AR, VR, and multi-sensory experiences. AR/VR adoption remained limited and Meta's pivot underperformed. Conversational AI succeeded, but that's not what 'immersive experience' meant — it was about spatial computing and sensory interfaces. Giving credit for ChatGPT here would be a stretch.

name: Blockchain
description: Blockchain would mature and become more practical, with improvements in scalability, interoperability, and smart contracts enabling real enterprise adoption.
accuracyNote: Still overhyped — despite technological improvements, enterprise blockchain adoption remained limited. Most pilot projects didn't scale to production.

name: Smart Spaces
description: Physical environments (offices, cities, factories) would become increasingly connected and intelligent, responding to occupants and optimizing operations.
accuracyNote: Partial — smart buildings and factories made progress, but COVID disrupted smart office investment. Smart city initiatives remain fragmented.

name: Digital Ethics and Privacy
description: Privacy, trust, and ethics would become critical concerns. Organizations would need to address growing public and government scrutiny around data use and AI bias.
accuracyNote: Extremely accurate — GDPR enforcement, AI ethics debates, AI regulation (EU AI Act), and privacy legislation (CCPA) all materialized. One of Gartner's most important calls.

name: Quantum Computing
description: Quantum computing would progress from experimental to practical applications within 5-10 years, with organizations needing to understand its potential impact.
accuracyNote: Premature — quantum computing in 2026 remains experimental with limited practical applications. The 'quantum advantage' for business problems is still years away.
